September

Feb 24, 2008

September streams steam in early morning.
Snowbirds stand shoulder to shoulder in preparation for the snow.
Some songbirds, however, are adverse:
steadfastly singing summer songs.

Ever changing events of weather ease through
the erudite forests which soon will be exfoliated.
An evening walk evokes in one both spring and fall.

Perpetual pictures of a summer soon to pass
posess a fleeting, poignant, palpable loss of time.
Pine boughs will soon put forth their pins.
Tiptoeing to a tune of inner urgency,
tripping over toys which talk (thanks tonton)
and to the coffee pot, two teaspoons, and a tumbler.

Eulogizing year’s past events though, even still,
there’s time for espisodic encounters with a morning or two
of easing out a line into the water as the evening turns to dawn.

Most of all is the memory of a moment;
a miracle of myself and of my wife.
Madly driving, much too fast, to meet her

Birth.
A baby born to both of us, blessed we were
with a bouncing, babbling, even bawling bitsy one.

Even as she ever grows and changes,
I end each day with awe and endless wonder,

reminded of the rapt and restless person
who readily and constantly demands my recognition.
This rosy-cheeked rascal of four years,
punctuates my remembrances of

September.
